revision.text:
The '''pseudo Jahn–Teller effect''' (PJTE), occasionally also known as '''second-order JTE''', is a direct extension of the [[Jahn–Teller effect]] (JTE) where [[spontaneous symmetry breaking]] in polyatomic systems ([[molecules]] and [[solids]]) occurs even in [[Degenerate energy levels|nondegenerate electronic states]] under the influence of sufficiently low-lying excited states of appropriate symmetry. "The pseudo Jahn–Teller effect is the only source of instability and distortions of high-symmetry configurations of polyatomic systems in nondegenerate states, and it contributes significantly to the instability in degenerate states".<ref name="Bersuker13">I. B. Bersuker, The Pseudo Jahn–Teller Effect – a Two-State Paradigm in Formation, Deformation, and Transformation of Molecular Systems and Solids, Chem. Rev., 113, 1351-1390 (2013).</ref>
==History==
In the first publication in 1957 on the (what is now called) pseudo Jahn–Teller effect (PJTE), Öpik and Pryce<ref name="Öpik">U. Öpik, and M. H. L. Pryce, "Studies of the Jahn Teller Effect.1. A Survey of the Static Problem". Proc. R. Soc. A. 238 (1215): 425–447 (1957). doi:10.1098/rspa.1957.0010</ref> showed that a small splitting of the degenerate electronic term does not necessarily remove the instability and distortion of the polyatomic system induced by the [[Jahn–Teller effect]] (JTE), provided the splitting is sufficiently small (the two split states remain “pseudodegenerate”), and the vibronic coupling between them is strong enough. From another perspective, the idea of vibronic admixture of different electronic terms by low-symmetry vibrations was introduced in 1933 by Herzberg and Teller<ref>G. Herzberg, and E. Teller, "Vibrational structure of electronic transitions for polyatomic molecules", Z. Phys. Chem. B, 21, 410 (1933).</ref> to explore forbidden electronic transitions, and extended in the late 1950s by Murrell and Pople<ref>J. N. Murrell, and J. A. Pople, "The intensities of the symmetry-forbidden electronic bands of benzene", Proc. Phys. Soc. London, Ser. A, 69, 245 (1956).</ref> and by Liehr.<ref>A. D. Liehr, "Interaction of the vibrational and electronic motion in some simple conjugated hydrocarbons. I. Exact calculation of the intensity of the <sup>1</sup>A<sub>1g</sub> → <sup>1</sup>B1u, 1B2u, vibronic transitions of benzene", Z. Naturforsch. a 13, 311 (1958).</ref> The role of excited states in softening the ground state with respect to distortions in benzene was demonstrated qualitatively by Longuet-Higgins and Salem<ref>H. C. Longuet-Higgins, L. Salem, Proc. R. Soc. London, A 251, 172 (1959).</ref> by analyzing the [[pi bond|π electron levels]] in the [[Hückel method|Hückel approximation]], while a general second-order perturbation formula for such vibronic softening was derived by Bader in 1960.<ref>R. F. W. Bader, Mol. Phys. 3, 137 (1960).</ref> In 1961 Fulton and Gouterman<ref>R.L. Fulton and M. Gouterman, J. Chem. Phys. 35, 1059 (1961).</ref> presented a symmetry analysis of the two-level case in [[dimer (chemistry)|dimer]]s and introduced the term "pseudo Jahn–Teller effect". The first application of the PJTE to solving a major solid-state structural problem with regard to the origin of [[ferroelectricity]] was published in 1966 by Bersuker,<ref name="Bersuker66">I. B. Bersuker, "On the origin of ferroelectricity in perovskite-type crystals", Phys. Lett. 20, 589 (1966).</ref> and the first book on the JTE covering the PJTE was published in 1972 by Englman.<ref name="Englman72">R. Englman "The Jahn–Teller Effect in Molecules and Crystals", Wiley-Interscience, (1972). {{ISBN|9780471241683}}</ref> The second-order perturbation approach was employed by Pearson in 1975 to predict instabilities and distortions in molecular systems;<ref name="Pearson76">G. Pearson, "Symmetry Rules for Chemical Reactions. Orbital Topology for Elementary Processes", Wiley: New York, 1976.</ref> he called it "second-order JTE" (SOJTE). The first explanation of PJT origin of puckering distortion as due to the vibronic coupling to the excited state was given for the N<sub>3</sub>H<sub>3</sub><sup>2+</sup> radical by Borden, Davidson, and Feller in 1980<ref>W. T. Borden, E. R. Davidson, and D. Feller, J. Am. Chem. Soc. 102, 5302 (1980).</ref> (they called it "piramidalization"). Methods of numerical calculation of the PJT vibronic coupling effect with applications to spectroscopic problems were developed in the early 1980s<ref>H. Köppel, W. Domcke, and L. S. Cederbaum, Adv. Chem. Phys. 57, 59 (1984); Adv. Chem. Phys. 67, 59 (1986).</ref> A significant step forward in this field was achieved in 1984 when it was shown by numerical calculations<ref>I. B. Bersuker, N. N. Gorinchoy, and V. Z. Polinger, "On the origin of dynamic instability of molecular systems", Theor. Chim. Acta, 66, 161 (1984).</ref> that the energy gap to the active excited state may not be the ultimate limiting factor in the PJTE, as there are two other compensating parameters in the condition of instability. It was also shown that, in extension of the initial definition,<ref name="Öpik"/> the PJT interacting electronic states are not necessarily components emerging from the same symmetry type (as in the split degenerate term). As a result, the applicability of the PJTE became ''a priory'' unlimited. Moreover, it was shown by Bersuker that the PJTE is the only source of instability of high-symmetry configurations of polyatomic systems in nondegenerate states (works cited in Refs.<ref name="Bersuker13"/><ref name="BP89">I. B. Bersuker and V. Z. Polinger, "Vibronic Interactions in Molecules and Crystals", Springer-Verlag, Berlin-Heidelberg-New York, 1989.</ref><ref name="Bersuker06">I. B. Bersuker, "The Jahn–Teller effect", Cambridge University Press, Cambridge UK, 2006.</ref>), and degeneracy and pseudodegeneracy are the only source of [[spontaneous symmetry breaking]] in matter in all its forms.<ref name="Bersuker16">I. B. Bersuker, "Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking in Matter Induced by Degeneracy and Pseudodegeneracy", in Advances in Chemical Physics, Vol. 160, S. Rice and R. Dinner, eds., Wiley, New York, 2016, pp159-208.</ref> The many applications of the PJTE to the study of a variety of properties of molecular systems and solids are reflected in a number of reviews and books <ref name="Bersuker13"/><ref name="Englman72"/><ref name="Pearson76"/><ref name="BP89"/><ref name="Bersuker06"/><ref name="Bersuker16"/><ref name="Burdett80">J. K. Burdett, "Molecular Shapes. Theoretical Models of Inorganic Stereochemistry", Wiley: New York, 1980.</ref><ref name="Hoffmann88">R. Hoffmann, "Solids and Surfaces: A Chemist’s View of Bonding in Extended Structures", VCH: New York, 1988.</ref>), as well as in proceedings of conferences on the JTE.
==Theoretical background==
===General theory===
The equilibrium geometry of any polyatomic system in nondegenerate states is defined as corresponding to the point of the minimum of the [[potential energy surface|adiabatic potential energy surface]] (APES), where its first derivatives are zero and the second derivatives are positive. Denote the energy of the system as a function of normal displacements Q<sub>α</sub> by E(Q<sub>α</sub>). At the point of minimum (Q<sub>α</sub>=0) of the APES the curvature K of E(Q<sub>α</sub>) in the Q direction,
K = (d<sup>2</sup>E/dQ<sub>α</sub><sup>2</sup>)<sub>0</sub> (1)
is positive, K > 0. Very often the geometry of the system at this point of equilibrium on the APES does not coincide with the highest possible (or even with any high) symmetry expected from general symmetry considerations. For instance, linear molecules are bent at equilibrium, planar molecules are puckered, octahedral complexes are elongated, or compressed, or tilted, cubic crystals are tetragonally polarized (or have several structural phases), etc. The PJTE is the general driving force of all these distortions if they occur in the nondegenerate electronic states of the high-symmetry (reference) geometry. If at the reference configuration the system is structurally unstable with respect to some nuclear displacements Q<sub>α</sub>, than K < 0 in this direction. The general formula for the energy is E = <ψ<sub>0</sub>|H|ψ<sub>0</sub>>, where H is the Hamiltonian and ψ<sub>0</sub> is the wavefunction of the nondegenerate ground state. Substituting E in Eq.(1), we get (omitting the α index for simplicity)<ref name="Bersuker13"/>
K=K<sub>0</sub> + K<sub>v</sub> (2)
K<sub>0</sub>=<ψ<sub>0</sub>|(d<sup>2</sup>H/dQ<sup>2</sup>)<sub>0</sub>|ψ<sub>0</sub>> (3)
K<sub>v</sub>=-Σ<sub>n</sub>|<ψ<sub>0</sub>|(dH/dQ)<sub>0</sub>|ψ<sub>n</sub>>|<sup>2</sup>/[E<sub>n</sub>-E<sub>0</sub>] (4)
where ψ<sub>n</sub> are the wavefunctions of the excited states, and the K<sub>v</sub> expression, obtained as a second order perturbation correction, is always negative, K<sub>v</sub><0. Therefore, if K<sub>0</sub>>0, the K<sub>v</sub> contribution is the only source of instability. The matrix elements in Eq. (4) are off-diagonal [[vibronic coupling]] constants,<ref name="Englman72"/><ref name="BP89"/><ref name="Bersuker06"/>
F<sub>0n</sub>= <ψ<sub>0</sub>|(dH/dQ)<sub>0</sub>|ψ<sub>n</sub>> (5)
They measure the mixing of the ground and excited states under the nuclear displacements Q, and therefore K<sub>v</sub> is termed the vibronic contribution. Together with the K<sub>0</sub> value and the energy gap 2∆<sub>0n</sub>=E<sub>n</sub>-E<sub>0</sub> between the mixing states, F<sub>0n</sub> are the main parameters of the PJTE (see below). In a series of papers beginning in 1980 (see references in <ref name="Bersuker13"/><ref name="BP89"/><ref name="Bersuker06"/>) it was proved that for any polyatomic system in the high-symmetry configuration
K<sub>0</sub>>0, (6)
and hence the vibronic contribution is the only source of instability of any polyatomic system in nondegenerate states. If K<sub>0</sub> >0 for the high-symmetry configuration of any polyatomic system, then a negative curvature, K =(K<sub>0</sub> + K<sub>v</sub>)< 0, can be achieved only due to the negative vibronic coupling component K<sub>v</sub>, and only if |K<sub>v</sub>|> K<sub>0</sub>. It follows that any distortion of the high-symmetry configuration is due to, and only to the mixing of its ground state with excited electronic states by the distortive nuclear displacements realized via the [[vibronic coupling]] in Eq. (5). The latter softens the system with respect to certain nuclear displacements (K<sub>v</sub><0), and if this softening is larger than the original (nonvibronic) hardness K<sub>0</sub> in this direction, the system becomes unstable with respect to the distortions under consideration, leading to its equilibrium geometry of lower symmetry, or to dissociation. There are many cases when neither the ground state is degenerate, nor is there a significant vibronic coupling to the lowest excited states to realize PJTE instability of the high-symmetry configuration of the system, and still there is a ground state equilibrium configuration with lower symmetry. In such cases the symmetry breaking is produced by a hidden PJTE (similar to a hidden JTE); it takes place due to a strong PJTE mixing of two excited states, one of which crosses the ground state to create a new (lower) minimum of the APES with a distorted configuration.<ref name="Bersuker13"/>
===The two-level problem===
The use of the second order perturbation correction, Eq. (4), for the calculation of the K<sub>v</sub> value in the case of PJTE instability is incorrect because in this case |K<sub>v</sub>|>K<sub>0</sub>, meaning the first perturbation correction is larger than the main term, and hence the criterion of applicability of the [[perturbation theory]] in its simplest form does not hold. In this case, we should consider the contribution of the lowest excited states (that make the total curvature negative) in a pseudodegenerate problem of perturbation theory. For the simplest case when only one excited state creates the main instability of the ground state, we can treat the problem via a pseudodegenerate two-level problem, including the contribution of the higher, weaker-influencing states as a second order correction.<ref name="Bersuker13"/> In the PJTE two-level problem we have two electronic states of the high-symmetry configuration, ground β and excited γ, separated by an energy interval of 2Δ, that become mixed under nuclear displacements of certain symmetry Q=Q<sub>α</sub>; the denotations α, β, and γ indicate, respectively, the irreducible representations to which the symmetry coordinate and the two states belong. In essence, this is the original formulation of the PJTE. Assuming that the excited state is sufficiently close to the ground one, the [[vibronic coupling]] between them should be treated as a perturbation problem for two near-degenerate states. With both interacting states non-degenerate the vibronic coupling constant F in Eq.(5) (omitting indices)is non-zero for only one coordinate Q=Q<sub>α</sub> with α=β×γ. This gives us directly the symmetry of the direction of softening and possible distortion of the ground state. Assuming that the primary force constants K<sub>0</sub> in the two states are the same (for different K<sub>0</sub> see [1]), we get a 2×2 secular equation with the following solution for the energies ε<sub>±</sub> of the two states interacting under the linear vibronic coupling (the energy is read off the middle of the 2Δ interval between the initial levels):
ε<sub>±</sub>= (1/2)Q<sup>2</sup>±[Δ<sup>2</sup>+F<sup>2</sup>Q<sup>2</sup>]<sup>(1/2)</sup> (7)
It is seen from this expressions that, on taking into account the vibronic coupling, F≠0, the two APES curves change in different ways: in the upper sheet the curvature (the coefficient at Q<sup>2</sup> in the expansion on Q) increases, whereas in the lower one it decreases. But until (F<sup>2</sup>/K<sub>0</sub>)<Δ the minima of both states correspond to the point Q = 0, as in the absence of vibronic mixing. However, if
(F<sup>2</sup>/K<sub>0</sub>)>Δ (8)
the curvature of the lower curve of the APES becomes negative, and the system is unstable with respect to the Q displacements (Fig. 1). The minima points on the APES in this case are given by
±Q<sub>0</sub>=[F<sup>2</sup>/K<sub>0</sub><sup>2</sup>-Δ<sup>2</sup>/F<sup>2</sup>]<sup>1/2</sup> (9)
From these expressions and Fig. 1 it is seen that while the ground state is softened (destabilized) by the PJTE, the excited state is hardened (stabilized), and this effect is the larger, the smaller Δ and the larger F. It takes place in any polyatomic system and influences many molecular properties, including the existence of stable excited states of molecular systems that are unstable in the ground state (e.g., excited states of intermediates of chemical reactions); in general, even in the absence of instability the PJTE softens the ground state and increases the vibrational frequencies in the excited state.
===Comparison with the JTE. Added covalency is driving PJTE distortions===
[[File:Jahn-Teller and pseudo Jahn-Teller effects.svg|thumb|upright=1.5|Fig. 1. Energy profiles in a two-level PJTE (lower - b) versus the JTE (upper - a) in a single distortion coordinate Q.]] The two branches of the APES for the case of strong PJTE resulting in the instability of the ground state (when the condition of instability (11) holds) are illustrated in Fig. 1b in comparison with the case when the two states have the same energy (Fig. 1a), i. e. when they are degenerate and the Jahn–Teller effect (JTE) takes place. We see that the two cases, degenerate and nondegenerate but close-in-energy (pseudodegenerate) are similar in generating two minima with distorted configurations, but there are important differences: while in the JTE there is a crossing of the two terms at the point of degeneracy (leading to conical intersections in more complicated cases), in the nondegenerate case with strong vibronic coupling there is an “avoided crossing” or “pseudo crossing”. Even a more important difference between the two vibronic coupling effects emerges from the fact that the two interacting states in the JTE are components of the same symmetry type, whereas in the PJTE each of the two states may have any symmetry. For this reason the possible kinds of distortion is very limited in the JTE, and unlimited in the PJTE. It is also noticeable that while the systems with JTE are limited by the condition of electron degeneracy, the applicability of the PJTE has no a priori limitations, as it includes also the cases of degeneracy. Even when the PJT coupling is weak and the inequality (11) does not hold, the PJTE is still significant in softening (lowering the corresponding vibrational frequency) of the ground state and increasing it in the excited state.<ref name="Bersuker13"/> When considering the PJTE in an excited state, all the higher in energy states destabilize it, while the lower ones stabilize it.
[[File:Fig. 2 Illustration to the origin of the PJTE as due to added covalence bonding by distortion.tif|thumb|Fig. 2. Illustration to the origin of the PJTE as due to added covalence bonding by distortion: (a) when the Fe atom in metalloporphyrins is in the porphyrin-ring in-plane position, the net overlap of its d<sub>z2</sub> orbital with the near-neighbor nitrogen p<sub>z</sub> orbitals is zero by symmetry, and these orbitals do not contribute to the bonding; (b) the out-of-plane displacement of Fe results in their non-zero overlap producing a covalence contribution to the bonding]] For a better understanding it is important to follow up on how the PJTE is related to intramolecular interactions. In other words, what is the physical driving force of the PJTE distortions (transformations) in terms of well-known electronic structure and bonding? The driving force of the PJTE is added (improved) covalence: the PJTE distortion takes place when it results in energy gain due to better covalence bonding between the atoms in the distorted configuration.<ref name="Bersuker13"/><ref name="Bersuker06"/> Indeed, in the starting high-symmetry configuration the wavefunctions of the electronic states, ground and excited, are orthogonal by definition. By distortion their orthogonality is violated, and a nonzero overlap between them occurs. If for two near-neighbor atoms the ground state wavefunction pertains (mainly) to one of them, while the excited state wavefunction belongs (mainly) to the other one, the overlap by distortion adds covalency to the bonding between them, facilitating the distortion (Fig. 2).
==Applications== Applications of the PJTE to solving chemical, physical, biological, and [[materials science]] problems are innumerable; as stated above, the PJTE is the only source of instability and distortions in high-symmetry configurations of molecular systems and solids with nondegenerate states, hence any problem steaming from such instability can be treated by the PJTE. Below are some illustrative examples.
=== Linear systems === '''PJTE versus [[Renner–Teller effect]] in bending distortions'''. Linear molecules are exceptions from the JTE, and for a long time it was assumed that their bending distortions in degenerate states (observed in many molecules) is produced by the Renner–Teller effect (RTE) (the splitting of the generate state by the quadratic terms of the vibronic coupling). However, recently it was proved (see in the review <ref name="Bersuker13"/>) that the RTE, by splitting the degenerate electronic state, just softens the lower branch of the APES, but this lowering of the energy is not enough to overcome the rigidity of the linear configuration and to produce bending distortions. It follows that the bending distortion of linear molecular systems is due to, and only to the PJTE that mixes the electronic state under consideration with higher in energy (excited) states. This statement is enhanced by the fact that many linear molecules in nondegenerate states (and hence with no RTE) are, too, bent in the equilibrium configuration. The physical reason for the difference between the PJTE and the RTE in influencing the degenerate term is that while in the former case the vibronic coupling with the excited state produces additional covalent bonding that makes the distorted configuration preferable (see above, section 2.3), the RTE has no such influence; the splitting of the degenerate term in the RTE takes place just because the charge distribution in the two states becomes nonequivalent under the bending distortion.
'''[[Peierls distortion]]s in linear chains'''. In linear molecules with three or more atoms there may be PJTE distortions that do not violate the linearity but change the interatomic distances. For instance, as a result of the PJTE a centrosymmetric linear system may become non-centrosymmetric in the equilibrium configurations, as, for example, in the BNB molecule (see in <ref name="Bersuker13"/>). An interesting extension of such distortions in sufficiently long (infinite) linear chains was first considered by Peierls.<ref>R. E. Peierls "Quantum theory of solids", Oxford, Clarendon, 1955.</ref> In this case the electronic states, combinations of atomic states, are in fact band states, and it was shown that if the chain is composed by atoms with unpaired electrons, the valence band is only half filled, and the PJTE interaction between the occupied and unoccupied band states leads to the doubling of the period of the linear chain (see also in the books <ref name="BP89"/><ref name="Bersuker06"/>).
'''Broken cylindrical symmetry'''. It was shown also that the PJTE not only produces the bending instability of linear molecules, but if the mixing electronic states involve a Δ state (a state with a nonzero momentum with respect to the axis of the molecule, its projection quantum number being Λ=2), the APES, simultaneously with the bending, becomes warped along the coordinate of rotations around the molecular axis, thus violating both the linear and cylindrical symmetry.<ref>W. Hermoso, Y. Liu, and I. B. Bersuker, "A Novel Effect Induced by Pseudo Jahn–Teller Interactions: Broken Cylindrical Symmetry in Linear Molecules", J. Chem. Theory Comput., 10, 4377 (2014).</ref> It happens because the PJTE, by mixing the wavefunctions of the two interacting states, transfers the high momentum of the electrons from states with Λ=2 to states with lower momentum, and this may alter significantly their expected rovibronic spectra.
=== Nonlinear molecules and two-dimensional (2D) systems=== '''PJTE and combined PJTE plus JTE effects in molecular structures'''. There is a practically unlimited number of molecular systems for which the origin of their structural properties was revealed and/or rationalized based on the PJTE, or a combination of the PJTE and JTE. The latter stems from the fact that in any system with a JTE in the ground state the presence of a PJT active excited state is not excluded, and vice versa, the active excited state for the PJTE of the ground one may be degenerate, and hence JT active. Examples are shown, e.g., in Refs.,<ref name="Bersuker13"/><ref name="Englman72"/><ref name="Pearson76"/><ref name="BP89"/><ref name="Bersuker16"/><ref name="Burdett80"/><ref name="Hoffmann88"/> including molecular systems like Na<sub>3</sub>, C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>3</sub>, C<sub>4</sub>X<sub>4</sub> (X= H, F, Cl, Br), CO<sub>3</sub>, Si<sub>4</sub>R<sub>4</sub> (with R as large ligands), planar cyclic C<sub>n</sub>H<sub>n</sub>, all kind of coordination systems of transition metals, mixed-valence compounds, biological systems, origin of conformations, geometry of ligands’ coordination, etc., etc. In fact it is difficult to find a molecular system for which the PJTE implications are a priori excluded, which is understandable in view of the mentioned above unique role of the PJTE in such instabilities.
[[File:Ab initio calculated energy profiles of CuF3 in the ground and lowest excited states as a function of the angle F-Cu-F.png|thumb|Fig. 3. Ab initio calculated energy profiles of CuF<sub>3</sub> in the ground and lowest excited states as a function of the angle α, typical for this class of electronic e<sub>2</sub> configurations, showing the formation of two equilibrium geometries by the PJTE on two excited states, one of which is undistorted, but magnetic, the other being distorted, but nonmagnetic]] '''Hidden PJTE, [[spin crossover]], and [[magnetic-dielectric bistability]]'''. As mentioned above, there are molecular systems in which the ground state in the high-symmetry configuration is neither degenerate to trigger the JTE, nor does it interact with the low-lying excited states to produce the PJTE (e.g., because of their different spin multiplicity). In these situations the instability is produced by a strong PJTE in the excited states; this is termed “hidden PJTE” in the sense that its origin is not seen explicitly as a PJTE in the ground state. An interesting typical situation of hidden PJTE emerges in molecular and solid state systems with valence half-filed closed shells electronic configurations e<sup>2</sup> and t<sup>3</sup>. For instance, in the e<sup>2</sup> case the ground state in the high-symmetry equilibrium geometry is an orbital non-degenerate triplet <sup>3</sup>A, while the nearby low-lying two excited electronic states are close-in-energy singlets <sup>1</sup>E and <sup>1</sup>A; due to the strong PJT interaction between the latter, the lower component of <sup>1</sup>E crosses the triplet state to produce a global minimum with lower symmetry. Fig. 3 illustrates the hidden PJTE in the CuF<sub>3</sub> molecule, showing also the singlet-triplet spin crossover and the resulting two coexisting configurations of the molecule: high-symmetry (undistorted) spin-triplet state with a nonzero magnetic moment, and a lower in energy dipolar-distorted singlet state with zero magnetic moment. Such [[magnetic-dielectric bistability]] is inherent to a whole class of molecular systems and solids.<ref name="GB12">P. Garcia-Fernandez and I. B. Bersuker, Class of molecular and solid state systems with correlated magnetic and dielectric bistabilities induced by the pseudo Jahn–Teller effect, Phys. Rev. Lett. 106, 246406 (2011).</ref>
'''Puckering in planar molecules and graphene-like 2D and quasi 2D systems'''. Special attention has been paid recently to two-dimensional (2D) systems in view of a variety of their planar-surface-specific physical and chemical properties and possible graphene-like applications in electronics. Similar-to-[[graphene]] properties are sought for in silicene, phosphorene, boron nitride, zinc oxide, gallium nitride, as well as in other attractive subjects like 2D transition metal dichalcogenids and oxides, and there is a number of other organic and inorganic 2D and quasi-2D compounds with expected similar properties. One of the main important features of these systems is their planarity or quasi-planarity, but many of the quasi-2D compounds are subject to out-of-plane deviations known as puckering (buckling). It was shown, as expected, that the instability and distortions of the planar configuration (as in any other systems in nondegenerate state) is due to the PJTE.<ref name="Bersuker13"/><ref name="BP89"/><ref name="Bersuker06"/> Detailed exploration of the PJTE in such systems allows one to reveal the excited states that are responsible for the puckering, and suggest possible external influence that restores their planarity, including oxidation, reduction, substitutions, or coordination to other species.<ref name="Bersuker06"/><ref>I. B. Bersuker, The Jahn–Teller and pseudo Jahn–Teller effect in materials science, in Proc. 23th International conference on the Jahn–Teller effect, J. Phys. Conf. Series, 2017.</ref>
=== Solid state and materials science === '''Cooperative PJTE in [[BaTiO3|BaTiO<sub>3</sub>]]-type crystals and [[ferroelectricity]]'''. In crystals with PJTE centers the interaction between the local distortions may lead to their ordering to produce a phase transition to a regular crystal phase with lower symmetry. Such cooperative PJTE is quite similar to the cooperative JTE; it was shown in one of the first applications of the PJTE to solid state systems <ref name="Bersuker66"/> that in case of ABO<sub>3</sub> crystals with perovskite structure the local dipolar PJTE distortions at the transition metal B center and their cooperative interactions leads to ferroelectric phase transitions. Provided the criterion of PJTE is obeyed, each [BO<sub>6</sub>] center has an APES with eight equivalent minima along the trigonal axes, six orthorhombic, and (higher) twelve tetragonal saddle-points between them. With temperature, the gradually reached transitions between the minima via the different kind of saddle-points explains the origin of all the four phases (three ferroelectric and one paraelectric) in perovskites of the type BaTiO<sub>3</sub> and their properties. The predicted by the theory trigonal displacement of the Ti ion in all four phases, the fully disordered PJTE distortions in the paraelectric phase, and their partially disordered state in two other phases was confirmed by a variety of experimental investigations (see in <ref name="Bersuker13"/><ref name="Bersuker66"/><ref name="BP89"/><ref name="Bersuker06"/>).
'''[[Multiferroicity]] and magnetic-ferroelectric crossover'''. The PJTE theory of [[ferroelectricity]] in ABO3 crystals was expanded to show that, dependent of the number of electrons in the d<sup>n</sup> shell of the transition metal ion B<sup>4+</sup> and their low spin or high spin arrangement (which controls the symmetry and spin multiplicity of the ground and PJTE active excited states of the [BO<sub>6</sub>] center), their ferroelectricity may coexist with a magnetic moment ([[multiferroicity]]). Moreover, in combination with the temperature dependent spin crossover phenomenon (which changes the spin multiplicity), this kind of multiferroicity may lead to a novel effect of magnetic-ferroelectric crossover.<ref>I. B. Bersuker, Pseudo Jahn–Teller Origin of Perovskite Multiferroics, Magnetic-Ferroelectric Crossover, and Magnetoelectric Effects. The d<sup>0</sup>-d<sup>10</sup> problem, Phys. Rev. Lett., 108, 137202 (2012).</ref>
'''Solid state magnetic-dielectric bistability'''. Similar to the mentioned above molecular bistability induced by the hidden PJTE, a magnetic-dielectric bistability due to two coexisting equilibrium configurations with corresponding properties may take place also in crystals with transition metal centers, subject to the electronic configuration with half-filled e<sup>2</sup> or t<sup>3</sup> shells.<ref name="GB12"/> As in molecular systems, the latter produce a hidden PJTE and local bistability which, distinguished from the molecular case, are enhanced by the cooperative interactions, thus acquiring larger lifetimes. This crystal bistability was proved by calculations for LiCuO<sub>2</sub> and NaCuO<sub>2</sub> crystals, in which the Cu<sup>3+</sup> ion has the electronic e<sup>2</sup>(d<sup>8</sup>) configuration (similar to the CuF<sub>3</sub> molecule).<ref name="GB12"/>
'''Giant enhancement of observable properties in interaction with external perturbations'''. In a recent development of the PJTE applications in materials science it was shown that in crystals with PJTE centers, in which the local distortion are not ordered (before the phase transition to the cooperative phases), the effect of interaction with external perturbations acquires an orientational contribution which enhances the observable properties by several orders of magnitude. This was demonstrated on the properties of crystals like paraelectric BaTiO<sub>3</sub> in interaction with electric fields (in [[permittivity]] and [[electrostriction]]), or under a strain gradient ([[flexoelectricity]]). These giant enhancement effects occur due to the dynamic nature of the PJTE local dipolar distortions (their tunneling between the equivalent minima); the independently rotating dipole moments on each center become oriented (frozen) along the external perturbation resulting in an orientational polarization which is not there in the absence of the PJTE<ref>I. B. Bersuker, Giant Permittivity and Electrostriction induced by Dynamic Jahn–Teller and Pseudo Jahn–Teller Effects, Appl. Phys. Lett. 107, 202904 (2015); Pseudo Jahn–Teller effect in the origin of enhanced flexoelectricity, Appl. Phys. Lett. 106, 022903 (2015).</ref>

In [[classical mechanics]], '''action-angle coordinates''' are a set of [[canonical coordinates]] useful in solving many [[integrable system]]s. The method of action-angles is useful for obtaining the [[frequency|frequencies]] of oscillatory or rotational motion without solving the [[equations of motion]]. Action-angle coordinates are chiefly used when the [[Hamilton–Jacobi equation]]s are completely separable. (Hence, the [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)|Hamiltonian]] does not depend explicitly on time, i.e., the [[conservation of energy|energy is conserved]].) Action-angle variables define an '''invariant torus''', so called because holding the action constant defines the surface of a [[torus]], while the angle variables parameterize the coordinates on the torus.
The [[Bohr–Sommerfeld quantization]] conditions, used to develop quantum mechanics before the advent of [[Schrödinger equation#Particles as waves|wave mechanics]], state that the action must be an integral multiple of [[Planck's constant]]; similarly, [[Albert Einstein|Einstein]]'s insight into [[Einstein–Brillouin–Keller method|EBK quantization]] and the difficulty of quantizing non-integrable systems was expressed in terms of the invariant tori of action-angle coordinates.
Action-angle coordinates are also useful in [[perturbation theory]] of [[Hamiltonian mechanics]], especially in determining [[adiabatic invariant]]s. One of the earliest results from [[chaos theory]], for the non-linear perturbations of dynamical systems with a small number of degrees of freedom is the [[KAM theorem]], which states that the invariant tori are stable under small perturbations.
The use of action-angle variables was central to the solution of the [[Toda lattice]], and to the definition of [[Lax pairs]], or more generally, the idea of the [[isospectral]] evolution of a system.
==Derivation== Action angles result from a [[Canonical_transformation#Type_2_generating_function|type-2]] [[canonical transformation]] where the generating function is [[Hamilton–Jacobi equation|Hamilton's characteristic function]] <math>W(\mathbf{q})</math> (''not'' Hamilton's principal function <math>S</math>). Since the original Hamiltonian does not depend on time explicitly, the new Hamiltonian <math>K(\mathbf{w}, \mathbf{J})</math> is merely the old Hamiltonian <math>H(\mathbf{q}, \mathbf{p})</math> expressed in terms of the new [[canonical coordinates]], which we denote as <math>\mathbf{w}</math> (the '''action angles''', which are the [[generalized coordinates]]) and their new generalized momenta <math>\mathbf{J}</math>. We will not need to solve here for the generating function <math>W</math> itself; instead, we will use it merely as a vehicle for relating the new and old [[canonical coordinates]].
Rather than defining the action angles <math>\mathbf{w}</math> directly, we define instead their generalized momenta, which resemble the [[action (physics)|classical action]] for each original [[generalized coordinate]]
:<math> J_{k} \equiv \oint p_k \, \mathrm{d}q_k </math>
where the integration path is implicitly given by the constant energy function <math>E=E(q_k,p_k)</math>. Since the actual motion is not involved in this integration, these generalized momenta <math>J_k</math> are constants of the motion, implying that the transformed Hamiltonian <math>K</math> does not depend on the conjugate [[generalized coordinates]] <math>w_k</math>
:<math> \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t} J_{k} = 0 = \frac{\partial K}{\partial w_k} </math>
where the <math>w_k</math> are given by the typical equation for a type-2 [[canonical transformation]]
:<math> w_k \equiv \frac{\partial W}{\partial J_k} </math>
Hence, the new Hamiltonian <math>K=K(\mathbf{J})</math> depends only on the new generalized momenta <math>\mathbf{J}</math>.
The dynamics of the action angles is given by [[Hamilton's equations]]
:<math> \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t} w_k = \frac{\partial K}{\partial J_k} \equiv \nu_k(\mathbf{J}) </math>
The right-hand side is a constant of the motion (since all the <math>J</math>'s are). Hence, the solution is given by
:<math> w_k = \nu_k(\mathbf{J}) t + \beta_k </math>
where <math>\beta_k</math> is a constant of integration. In particular, if the original [[generalized coordinate]] undergoes an oscillation or rotation of period <math>T</math>, the corresponding action angle <math>w_k</math> changes by <math>\Delta w_k = \nu_k (\mathbf{J}) T</math>.
These <math>\nu_k(\mathbf{J})</math> are the frequencies of oscillation/rotation for the original [[generalized coordinate]]s <math>q_k</math>. To show this, we integrate the net change in the action angle <math>w_k</math> over exactly one complete variation (i.e., oscillation or rotation) of its [[generalized coordinate]]s <math>q_k</math>
:<math> \Delta w_k \equiv \oint \frac{\partial w_k}{\partial q_k} \, \mathrm{d}q_k = \oint \frac{\partial^2 W}{\partial J_k \, \partial q_k} \, \mathrm{d}q_k = \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}J_k} \oint \frac{\partial W}{\partial q_k} \, \mathrm{d}q_k = \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}J_k} \oint p_k \, \mathrm{d}q_k = \frac{\mathrm{d}J_k}{\mathrm{d}J_k} = 1 </math>
Setting the two expressions for <math>\Delta w_{k}</math> equal, we obtain the desired equation
:<math> \nu_k(\mathbf{J}) = \frac{1}{T} </math>
The action angles <math>\mathbf{w}</math> are an independent set of [[generalized coordinates]]. Thus, in the general case, each original generalized coordinate <math>q_{k}</math> can be expressed as a [[Fourier series]] in ''all'' the action angles
:<math> q_k = \sum_{s_1=-\infty}^\infty \sum_{s_2 = -\infty}^\infty \cdots \sum_{s_N = -\infty}^\infty A^k_{s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_N} e^{i2\pi s_1 w_1} e^{i2\pi s_2 w_2} \cdots e^{i2\pi s_N w_N} </math>
where <math>A^k_{s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_N}</math> is the Fourier series coefficient. In most practical cases, however, an original generalized coordinate <math>q_k</math> will be expressible as a [[Fourier series]] in only its own action angles <math>w_k</math>
:<math> q_k = \sum_{s_k=-\infty}^\infty A^k_{s_k} e^{i2\pi s_k w_k} </math>
==Summary of basic protocol==
The general procedure has three steps:
# Calculate the new generalized momenta <math>J_{k}</math> # Express the original Hamiltonian entirely in terms of these variables. # Take the derivatives of the Hamiltonian with respect to these momenta to obtain the frequencies <math>\nu_k</math>
==Degeneracy==
In some cases, the frequencies of two different [[generalized coordinate]]s are identical, i.e., <math>\nu_k = \nu_l</math> for <math>k \neq l</math>. In such cases, the motion is called '''degenerate'''.
Degenerate motion signals that there are additional general conserved quantities; for example, the frequencies of the [[Kepler problem]] are degenerate, corresponding to the conservation of the [[Laplace–Runge–Lenz vector]].
Degenerate motion also signals that the [[Hamilton–Jacobi equation]]s are completely separable in more than one coordinate system; for example, the Kepler problem is completely separable in both [[spherical coordinates]] and [[parabolic coordinates]].

Goldstein, (1980) ''Classical Mechanics'', 2nd. ed., Addison-Wesley. {{ISBN|0-201-02918-9}} * [[Gennadi Sardanashvily|G. {{merge to|history of spectroscopy|date=November 2018}} {{Multiple issues|{{copy edit|date=November 2018}}{{sections|date=November 2018}}}}This branch of [[spectroscopy]] deals with radiation related to [[atom]]s that are stripped of several electrons (multiply ionized atoms (MIA), multiply charged ions, highly charged [[ion]]s). These are observed in very [[Plasma (physics)|hot plasmas]] (laboratory or astrophysical) or in [[Accelerator physics|accelerator]] experiments ([[Particle accelerator|beam-foil]], [[electron beam ion trap]] (EBIT)). The lowest exited electron shells of such ions decay into stable ground states producing photons in [[Ultraviolet|VUV]], [[Extreme ultraviolet|EUV]] and soft [[X-ray]] spectral regions (so-called resonance transitions).
== History == After [[Isaac Newton|Newton]]'s.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=GnAFAAAAQAAJ&dq=newton+opticks&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q=newton%20opticks&f=false|title=Opticks|last=Newton|first=I.|publisher=London|year=1730|isbn=|location=Dover, New York, 1952, 4th ed.|pages=}}</ref> discovery of spectral structure of white light (17th century) and subsequent studies of the nature of light ([[Robert Hooke|Hooke]],<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://digicoll.library.wisc.edu/cgi-bin/HistSciTech/HistSciTech-idx?id=HistSciTech.HookeMicro|title=Micrographia: or some physiological descriptions of minute bodies made by magnifying glasses with observations and inquiries thereupon…|last=Hooke|first=Robert|publisher=|year=1665|isbn=|location=|pages=47}}</ref> [[Christiaan Huygens|Huygens]],<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/14725|title=Traité de la lumière|last=Huygens|first=Christiaan|publisher=|year=1690|isbn=|location=Leyden|publication-date=1962|pages=}}</ref> [[Thomas Young (scientist)|Young]]<ref>T. Young, Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc. London xcii, 12, 387 (1802); ''Young's Works,'' Vol. 1, P. 202 .</ref>) [[Joseph von Fraunhofer|J. Fraunhofer]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fraunhofer|first=J.|date=1817|title=Bestimmung des Brechungs- und des Farbenzerstreuungs-Vermögens verschiedener Glasarten, in Bezug auf die Vervollkommnung achromatischer Fernröhre|url=|journal=Annalen der Physik |volume=56|pages=264–313|via=}}</ref> observed and measured dark lines in the Sun's spectrum (they bear now his name although several of them were observed earlier by [[William Hyde Wollaston|Wollaston]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wollaston|first=W. H.|date=1802|title=A method of examining refractive and dispersive powers, by prismatic reflection|url=http://rstl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/92/365.full.pdf+html|journal=Philos. Trans. R. Soc.|volume=92|pages=365–380|via=}}</ref>). It may be the first example of fundamental research in spectroscopy.
Later [[Robert Bunsen|Bunsen]] and [[Gustav Kirchhoff|Kirchhoff]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bunsen|first=R.|last2=Kirchhoff|first2=G.|date=1861|title=Untersuchungen über das Sonnenspektrum und die Spektren der Chemischen Elemente|url=|journal=Abhandl. Kgl. Akad. Wiss. Berlin|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> found that [[Fraunhofer lines]] correspond to emission spectral lines observed in laboratory light sources, and so they laid way for [[Spectrochemical Analysis|spectrochemical analysis]] in laboratory and astrophysics.
In the 19th century new developments such as the discovery of photography, [[Henry Augustus Rowland|Rowland's]]<ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1080/14786448208627217 | title=LXI. Preliminary notice of the results accomplished in the manufacture and theory of gratings for optical purposes| journal=The London, Edinburgh, and Dublin Philosophical Magazine and Journal of Science| volume=13| issue=84| pages=469–474| year=1882| last1=Rowland| first1=H.A.}}</ref> invention of the concave [[diffraction grating]], and [[Victor Schumann|Schumann's]]<ref>Schumann's papers are listed in T. Lyman, ''The Spectroscopy of the Extreme Ultraviolet'' (Longmans, Green and Company, London, 1928), 2nd ed.</ref> works on discovery of [[vacuum ultraviolet]] (fluorite for prisms and lenses, low-gelatin [[photographic plate]]s and absorption of UV in air below 185 [[Nanometre|nm]]) made advance to shorter wavelengths very fast. At the same time [[James Dewar|Dewar]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liveing|first=G.D.|last2=Dewar|first2=J.|date=1879|title=V. On the spectra of sodium and potassium|url=|journal=Proc. Roy. Soc. Lond.|volume=29|issue=196–199|pages=398–402|doi=10.1098/rspl.1879.0067|via=}}</ref> observed series in alkali spectra, [[Walter Noel Hartley|Hartley]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hartley|first=W.N.|date=1883|title=On Homologous Spectra|url=|journal=J. Chem. Soc. Lond.|volume=43|pages=390–400|doi=10.1039/CT8834300390|via=}}</ref> found constant wave-number differences, [[Johann Jakob Balmer|Balmer]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Balmer|first=J.J.|date=1885|title=Notiz über die Spectrallinien des Wasserstoffes|url=|journal=Annalen der Physik und Chemie|volume=25|pages=80|via=}}</ref> discovered a relation connecting wavelengths in the visible [[hydrogen]] spectrum, and finally [[Johannes Rydberg|Rydberg]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rydberg|first=J.R.|date=1890|title=Recherches sur la constitution des spectres d'émission des éléments chimiques|url=|journal=Kgl. Svenska Vetensk.-Akad. Handl., Stockh.|volume=23 |issue=11|pages=|via=}}</ref> derived a formula for [[Wavenumber|wave-numbers]] of spectral series.
The first decade of the 20th century brought the basics of [[Quantum mechanics|quantum theory]] ([[Max Planck|Plank]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Plank|first=M.|date=1901|title=On the distribution law of energy in the normal spectrum|url=|journal=Annalen der Physik|volume=4 |issue=4|pages=553|via=}}</ref> [[Albert Einstein|Einstein]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Einstein|first=Albert|date=1905|title=On a Heuristic Viewpoint Concerning the Production and Transformation of Light|url=http://lorentz.phl.jhu.edu/AnnusMirabilis/AeReserveArticles/eins_lq.pdf|journal=Annalen der Physik|volume=17|pages=132–148|via=}}</ref>) and interpretation of spectral series of hydrogen by [[Theodore Lyman|Lyman]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lyman|first=T.|date=1906|title=Preliminary Measurement of the Short Wave-Lengths Discovered by Schumann|url=|journal=Astrophys. J.|volume=19|pages=263|doi=10.1086/141111|via=}}</ref> in [[Vacuum ultraviolet|VUV]] and by [[Friedrich Paschen|Paschen]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Paschen|first=F.|date=1908|title=Zur Kenntnis ultraroter Linienspektra|url=|journal=Annalen der Physik|volume=27|pages=537–564|via=}}</ref> in [[infrared]]. [[Walther Ritz|Ritz]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ritz|first=W.|date=1908|title=Über ein neues Gesetz für Serienspektren|url=|journal=Phys. Z.|volume=9|pages=521|doi=10.1086/141591|via=}}</ref> formulated the [[Rydberg–Ritz combination principle|combination principle]].
In 1913 [[Niels Bohr|Bohr]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bohr|first=N.|date=1913|title=Abhandlungen ueber Atombau|url=|journal=Phil. Mag.|volume=26|pages=476|via=}}</ref> formulated his quantum mechanical model of atom. This stimulated empirical term analysis (see references in,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Edlén|first=B.|date=1964|title=Atomic Spectra|url=|journal=Handbuch der Physik|volume=27|pages=80–220|via=}}</ref> page 83).
Between 1920 and 1930 fundamental concepts of quantum mechanics were developed by [[Wolfgang Pauli|Pauli]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pauli|first=W.|date=1925|title=Über den Zusammenhang des Abschlusses der Elektronengruppen im Atom mit der Komplexstruktur der Spektren|url=|journal=Zeitschrift für Physik|volume=31|pages=765–783|doi=10.1007/BF02980631|via=}}</ref> [[Werner Heisenberg|Heisenberg]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Heisenberg|first=W.|date=1925|title=Über quantentheoretische Umdeutung kinematischer und mechanischer Beziehungen|url=|journal=Zeitschrift für Physik|volume=33|pages=879–893|doi=10.1007/BF01328377|via=}}</ref> [[Erwin Schrödinger|Schrödinger]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schrödinger|first=E.|date=1926|title=An Undulatory Theory of the Mechanics of Atoms and Molecules|url=|journal=Phys. Rev.|volume=28|issue=6|pages=1049–1070|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.28.1049|via=}}</ref> and [[Paul Dirac|Dirac]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dirac|first=P.A.M.|date=1928|title=The Quantum Theory of the Electron|url=|journal=Proc. Roy. Soc. Lond. A|volume=117|issue=778|pages=610–624|doi=10.1098/rspa.1928.0023}}</ref> Understanding of the [[Spin (physics)|spin]] and exclusion principle allowed conceiving how [[Electron configuration|electron shells]] of atoms are filled with the increasing [[atomic number]].
Further progress in studies of atomic structure was in tight connection with the advance to shorter [[wavelength]] in EUV region. [[Robert Andrews Millikan|Millikan]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Millikan|first=R.A.|last2=Sawyer|first2=R.A.|date=1919|title=Three fourth of an Octave farther in the Ultra-violet|url=|journal=Science|volume=50|issue=1284|pages=138–139|doi=10.1126/science.50.1284.138|pmid=17759610|via=}}</ref> [[Ralph A. Sawyer|Sawyer]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Millikan|first=R.A.|last2=Sawyer|first2=R.A.|date=1918|title=Extreme ultraviolet spectra of hot sparks in high vacuum|url=|journal=Phys. Rev.|volume=12|pages=168|via=}}</ref> [[Ira Sprague Bowen|Bowen]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Millikan|first=R.A.|last2=Bowen|first2=I.S.|date=1924|title=Extreme Ultra-violet Spectra|journal=Phys. Rev.|volume=23|pages=1–34|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.23.1}}</ref> used [[electric discharge]]s in vacuum to observe some emission spectral lines down to 13 nm they prescribed to stripped atoms. In 1927 Osgood<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Osgood|first=T.H.|date=1927|title=X-Ray Spectra of Long Wave-Length|journal=Phys. Rev.|volume=30|issue=5|pages=567–573|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.30.567}}</ref> and Hoag<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hoag|first=J.B.|date=1927|title=Wavelengths of Carbon, Oxygen, and Nitrogen in the Extreme Ultraviolet with a Concave Grating at Grazing Incidence|url=|journal=Astrophys. J.|volume=66|pages=225–232|via=}}</ref> reported on [[Grazing incidence diffraction|grazing incidence]] concave grating spectrographs and photographed lines down to 4.4 nm (K<sub>α</sub> of carbon). Dauvillier<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dauvillier|first=A.|date=1927|title=La spectrographie des rayons X de grande longueur d'onde. Séries N et O, et jonction avec l'ultraviolet extrême|url=|journal=J. Phys. Radium|volume=8|issue=1|pages=1–12|doi=10.1051/jphysrad:01927008010100|via=}}</ref> used a fatty acid crystal of large crystal grating space to extend soft x-ray spectra up to 12.1 nm, and the gap was closed. In the same period [[Manne Siegbahn]] constructed a very sophisticated grazing incidence spectrograph that enabled Ericson and [[Bengt Edlén|Edlén]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ericson|first=A.|last2=Edlén|first2=B.|date=1930|title=Serienspektren der leichtesten Elemente im extremen Ultraviolett|url=|journal=Z. Phys.|volume=59|pages=656–679|via=}}</ref> to obtain spectra of vacuum spark with high quality and to reliably identify lines of multiply ionized atoms up to O VI, with five stripped electrons. [[Walter Grotrian|Grotrian]]<ref>{{Cite book|title=Graphische Darstellung der Spektren von Atomen und Ionen mit ein, zwei und drei Valenzelektronen|last=Grotrian|first=W.|publisher=Springer-Verlag|year=1928|isbn=|editor-last=Born|editor-first=M.|location=Berlin|pages=|editor-last2=Franck|editor-first2=J.}}</ref> developed his graphic presentation of energy structure of the atoms. [[Henry Norris Russell|Russel]] and Saunders<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Russel|first=H.N.|last2=Saunders|first2=F.A.|date=1925|title=New Regularities in the Spectra of the Alkaline Earths|url=|journal=Astrophys. J.|volume=61|pages=38|doi=10.1086/142872|via=}}</ref> proposed their [[Angular momentum coupling|coupling]] scheme for the spin-orbit interaction and their generally recognized notation for [[Term symbol|spectral terms]].
Theoretical quantum-mechanical calculations become rather accurate to describe the energy structure of some simple electronic configurations. The results of theoretical developments were summarized by [[Edward Condon|Condon]] and Shortley<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Theory of Atomic Spectra|last=Condon|first=E.U.|last2=Shortley|first2=G.H.|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1935|isbn=|location=Cambridge|pages=}}</ref> in 1935.
[[Bengt Edlén|Edlén]] thoroughly analyzed spectra of MIA for many chemical elements and derived regularities in energy structures of MIA for many isoelectronic sequences (ions with the same number of electrons, but different nuclear charges). Spectra of rather high ionization stages (e.g. Cu XIX) were observed.
The most exciting event was in 1942, when [[Bengt Edlén|Edlén]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Edlén|first=B.|date=1942|title=Die Deutung der Emissionslinien im Spectrum der Sonnenkorona|url=|journal=Z. Astrophys.|volume=20|pages=30|via=}}</ref> proved the identification of some solar coronal lines on the basis of his precise analyses of spectra of MIA. This implied that the [[Corona|solar corona]] has a temperature of a million degrees, and strongly advanced understanding of solar and stellar physics.
After the [[World War II|WW II]] experiments on balloons and rockets were started to observe the VUV radiation of the Sun. (See [[X-ray astronomy]]). More intense research continued since 1960 including [[spectrometer]]s on satellites.
In the same period the laboratory spectroscopy of MIA becomes relevant as a diagnostic tool for hot plasmas of thermonuclear devices (see [[Nuclear fusion]]) which begun with building [[Stellarator]] in 1951 by Spitzer, and continued with [[tokamak]]s, z-pinches and the laser produced plasmas.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Martinson|first=I.|last2=Jupén|first2=C.|date=2003|title=Atomic Structure Studies Using Fusion Plasmas|url=|journal=Phys. Scr.|volume=68|issue=6|pages=123–132|doi=10.1238/physica.regular.068ac0123|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|last=Key|first=M.H.|last2=Hutcheon|first2=R.J.|date=1980|title=Spectroscopy of Laser-produced Plasmas|url=|journal=Advances in Atomic and Molecular Physics|volume=16|pages=201–280|doi=10.1007/978-94-017-0445-8_35|via=|isbn=978-94-017-0447-2}}</ref> Progress in ion [[Accelerator physics|accelerators]] stimulated beam-foil spectroscopy as a means to measure lifetimes of exited states of MIA.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Träbert|first=E.|date=2008|title=Beam–foil spectroscopy—Quo vadis|url=|journal=Phys. Scr.|volume=78|issue=3|pages=038103|doi=10.1088/0031-8949/78/03/038103|via=}}</ref> Many various data on highly exited energy levels, [[autoionization]] and inner-core ionization states were obtained. 
Simultaneously theoretical and computational approaches provided data necessary for identification of new spectra and interpretation of observed line intensities.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Judd|first=B.R.|date=1988|editor-last=Gschneidner, Jr|editor-first=K.A.|editor2-last=Eyring|editor2-first=L.|title=Atomic Theory and Optical Spectroscopy|url=|journal=Handbook on the Physics and Chemistry of Rare Earths|volume=11|pages=81–195|doi=10.1016/S0168-1273(88)11006-4|via=|isbn=9780444870803}}</ref> New laboratory and theoretical data become very useful for spectral observation in space.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Doschek|first=G.A.|last2=Feldman|first2=U.|date=2010|title=The Solar UV-X-ray Spectrum from 1.5 to 2000 Å|url=|journal=J. Phys. B|volume=43|issue=23|pages=232001|doi=10.1088/0953-4075/43/23/232001|via=}}</ref> It was a real upheaval of works on MIA in USA, England, France, Italy, Israel, Sweden, Russia and other countries<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fawcett|first=B.C.|date=1981|title=Classification of the Spectra of Highly Ionised Atoms During the Last Seven Years|url=|journal=Physica Scripta|volume=24|issue=4|pages=663–680|doi=10.1088/0031-8949/24/4/004|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Martinson|first=I.|date=1989|title=I. Martinson, The spectroscopy of highly ionised atoms, 52, 157 (1989)|url=|journal=Rep. Prog. Phys.|volume=52|issue=2|pages=157–225|doi=10.1088/0034-4885/52/2/002|via=}}</ref>
A new page in the spectroscopy of MIA may be dated as 1986 with development of [[Electron beam ion trap|EBIT]] (Levine and Marrs, [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory|LLNL]]) due to a favorable composition of modern high technologies such as [[cryogenics]], [[ultra-high vacuum]], [[superconducting magnet]]s, powerful [[Electron-beam technology|electron beams]] and [[semiconductor detector]]s. Very quickly EBIT sources were created in many countries (see [[National Institute of Standards and Technology|NIST]] summary<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nist.gov/pml/quantum-measurement/atomic-spectroscopy/electron-beam-ion-trap-ebit|title=Electron Beam Ion Trap (EBIT)|last=|first=|date=2009-10-06|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> for many details as well as reviews<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Beiersdorfer|first=P.|date=2009|title=Spectroscopy with trapped highly charged ions|url=https://e-reports-ext.llnl.gov/pdf/357087.pdf|journal=Phys. Scr.|volume=134|pages=014010|doi=10.1088/0031-8949/2009/T134/014010|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gillaspy|first=J.D.|date=2014|title=Precision spectroscopy of trapped highly charged heavy elements: pushing the limits of theory and experiment|url=|journal=Phys. Scr.|volume=89|issue=11|pages=114004 |doi=10.1088/0031-8949/89/11/114004|via=}}</ref>).
A wide field of spectroscopic research with EBIT is enabled including achievement of highest grades of ionization (U<sup>92+</sup>), wavelength measurement, [[hyperfine structure]] of energy levels, [[Quantum electrodynamics|quantum electrodynamic]] studies, ionization [[Cross section (physics)|cross-sections]] (CS) measurements, electron-impact excitation CS, X-ray [[Polarization (waves)|polarization]], relative line intensities, dielectronic [[Recombination (physics)|recombination]] CS, magnetic octupole decay, lifetimes of [[Forbidden mechanism|forbidden transitions]], charge-exchange recombination, etc.
